list.item: Encoding has been done using the recommendations for Level 3 of the "TEI in Libraries Guidelines."
Individual entries and page-breaks are encoded, but column breaks are omitted.
Print page headers and side descriptions are not included.
OCR successfully reproduced simple tables, but complex tabular data is not captured dependably and the results should not be relied upon.
OCR was not able to successfully reproduce math and chemical formulas. The uncorrected results remain in the text.
Some font formatting is preserved: italic, smallcaps, strikethrough, subscript, superscript, underline. The following print styles are ignored: bold, font size, typeface.

correction.p: This electronic text file was created by optical character recognition (OCR). OCR errors have not been corrected.
Illegible text in the original is indicated using unclear or gap, as appropriate. If corrected, the reference source is indicated with supplied.

normalization.p: Original spelling is preserved. When noticed, obvious misspellings are combined with the correct spelling as choice in the TEI. Ligatures are reproduced as multiple letters. Original footnote and marginal note sigla are replaced with sequential numbers for each entry.

punctuation.p: Extra space around punctuation marks is removed.

quotation.p: Quotation marks are retained as content in the text. Redundant open quotation marks at the start of lines inside block quotes are silently removed.

segmentation.p: The div type="entry" element divides the text into individual entries.
The div type="section" and div type="subsection" elements are reserved for future entry subsections.

projectDesc.p: All text was encoded for the Nineteenth-Century Knowledge Project to provide a machine-readable edition of the Encyclopedia Britannica to analyze using machine-learning methods.

Subject keywords are added to teiHeader for each entry; they were generated by the HIVE2 automated vocabulary server, created by the Metadata Research Center at Drexel University (https://hive2.cci.drexel.edu).

samplingDecl.p: This release reproduces the text matter for all entries. It does not include images, front- or back-matter. The reproduction of tables and formulae is unreliable.

div.p:
JUDAH Yehûda, i.e., according to the etymology given in Gen. xxix. 35, “praised ”), the name of one of the twelve tribes and of their eponymus the fourth son of Jacob by Leah. Except in the history of Joseph, the Biblical interest attaching to Judah belongs not to the individual but to the tribe; for in Gen. xxxviii. an ethnographical allegory appears transparently enough under the surface of the record. According to the usual form of such statements in the Old Testament, Judah’s marriage with the daughter of the Canaanite Shuah is to be referred to a union of the tribe with Canaanite elements. Er and Onan are extinct subdivisions of the mixed population, though a minor family of the former name appears as incorporated with Shelah, the third clan of this branch of the tribe (1 Chron. iv. 21). The details of the disappearance of these ancient stocks are obscure.
Compare the Arabic ⅛js, Sahih, Bulak ed. vi. 147; Λfοwatta, Cairo ed., iii. 77. The stocks of Pharez and Zerah are represented as secondary. They are children of Judah and Tamar, but the former is their father in virtue of an extension of the levirate principle. As the author represents Tamar’s conduct as justifiable under the circumstances, the narrative must have taken shape before the levirate law assumed the narrower form given in Deuteronomy.
Compare Hupfeld, Geberdieheutige theosophische Theologie, 1861. An ingenious explanation of Tamar, Pharez, and Zerah is given by Lagarde, Orientalia, ii. (1880). He identifies Tamar (palm tree) with Phoenicia, and regards Zerah (∏ΙT=ΓD1K, indigena) as the old Canaanite element of the union which had to yield precedence to the younger Hebrew invaders (Pharez). In any case the narrative of Gen. xxxviii., with all its obscurities, indicates two of the most notable features in the early history of Judah, its mixed character and its long separation from the rest of Israel (ver. 1). The latter point receives further illustration in the book of Judges. Judah and Simeon seem to have broken off from Israel at Gilgal, and taken a separate course. In the song of Deborah the tribe is not named among the rest, and even in the time of David Judah and Israel are still more conscious of their separation than of their original unity. Indeed the two soon fell apart again at the division of the kingdom, but after the time of David the idea of unity was never lost; and, while the prophets look for a restoration of the realm of the house of Jesse, Deut, xxxiii. 7 (the work of a poet of Ephraim) prays for victory to Judah against his enemies and his ultimate restoration to his people, the greater Israel of the north. The blessing of Jacob, on the other hand, views Judah in the light of the Davidic sovereignty as holding the hegemony over his brethren until the coming of the Messiah.
The oldest interpretation of Shiloh, as if it were pointed
(for ∏B*∏) is perhaps the best, especially if with Wellhausen {Gesch., p. 375) we delete the following <∣^η. The sense then is, “till he comes to whom the people’s obedience is due.” Another explanation is given by Lagarde {Oηorn., ii. 95), who takes the word as equivalent to ∏S'NEζ “he whom Judah prays for.” At all events the context demands a Messianic interpretation. Our most detailed information as to the tribal history of Judah is derived from 1 Chron. ii. l-iv. 23. It appears that the tribe absorbed a large element of non-Israelite origin, the Hezronites, or, as the Arabs would now say, the hadar, original nomads who had settled down in villages and towns. To these belonged not only the Jerahmeelites but the Calibbites in Hebron and the southern steppes. It appears to have been the incorporation of these elements that raised Judah to the eminent place which it maintained from the time of David. The details of this important piece of history have been analysed by Wellhausen, Degentibus et familiisJudaeorum (Göttingen, 1870).
